area: Hospital Management System Reliability and Compliance
context_of_use: The UHOPE organization configures and operates the hospital management system and the Electronic Medical Record Database so that it remains continuously available, GDPR compliant, properly backed up, capable of concurrent use by all employees, and integrated with the National Database for Medical Records.
scope: Hospital Management System including the Electronic Medical Record Database and its interfaces to the National Database for Medical Records and backup facilities
stakeholders_and_interests: UHOPE: Wants a hospital management system that is compliant with GDPR regulations to avoid legal and financial penalties.
UHOPE employees: Want the hospital management system and electronic medical record data to be available 24 hours per day and 7 days per week so they can always perform their job functions.
Patients: Want their medical records to be securely handled in compliance with GDPR and to be reliably available when needed for treatment.
Regulators and Data Protection Authorities: Require that the hospital management system complies with GDPR and applicable data protection regulations.
IT Operations Department: Wants clear operational requirements for availability, backups, concurrent access, and external integration to maintain reliable service.
Billing Department: Depends on continuous system and data availability to generate and verify bills correctly.
Clinical Staff (doctors, nurses, receptionists): Depend on continuous access to the hospital management system and electronic medical records to provide patient care.
National Database for Medical Records Operator: Expects consistent, accurate, and timely transfer of duplicated patient medical files from UHOPE.
description: This use case describes how UHOPE configures and operates the hospital management system to ensure GDPR compliance, continuous availability of the system and electronic medical record data, support for concurrent access by all employees, regular backups of all system information, access to the National Database for Medical Records, and duplication of patient medical files for transfer to the national database.
triggering_event: UHOPE decides to establish or review the operational configuration of the hospital management system to ensure reliability, compliance, availability, backup coverage, concurrent access capacity, and integration with the National Database for Medical Records.
preconditions: The hospital management system is deployed and under the operational control of UHOPE.
The Electronic Medical Record Database is operational within the hospital management system.
UHOPE has a valid organizational role and authority to define reliability, availability, backup, compliance, and integration requirements for the hospital management system.

A network connection between the hospital management system and external services, including the National Database for Medical Records and backup storage facilities, is established and available for configuration.
postconditions: The hospital management system is configured to provide online availability 24 hours per day and 7 days per week under normal operating conditions.
The Electronic Medical Record Database is configured so that its data is accessible 24 hours per day and 7 days per week under normal operating conditions.
The hospital management system is configured and documented to comply with applicable GDPR requirements for processing personal and medical data.
The hospital management system supports concurrent access for at least 7600 UHOPE employees.
At least one backup of every piece of information in the hospital management system is maintained at all times according to a defined backup strategy.
The Electronic Medical Record Database has established and configured access to the National Database for Medical Records.
The system duplicates each patient’s medical file in a form suitable for transfer to the National Database for Medical Records.
The operational configuration supporting reliability, availability, backups, concurrent access, GDPR compliance, and national database integration is recorded and under change control.
assumptions: It is assumed that "UHOPE" denotes the legal entity operating the hospital management system and that this entity can act as the primary actor in this use case.
It is assumed that UHOPE personnel responsible for system configuration perform the actions on behalf of the UHOPE actor, while the system behaviors are represented as system responses.

It is assumed that the requirement "online 24 hours per day and 7 days per week" refers to intended service availability under normal operating conditions and does not imply absolute technical impossibility of downtime.

It is assumed that the requirement to have at least one back-up at all times of every piece of information is fulfilled by a continuous or frequent backup mechanism that ensures no significant gap where data is entirely without a backup, without specifying a particular technology.

It is assumed that supporting actors such as "National Database for Medical Records", "Backup Storage Service", and "Network Infrastructure" exist as external systems or services that can be configured and used by the hospital management system.

It is assumed that GDPR compliance requirements are externally defined by applicable law and that this use case addresses system-side configuration and capabilities needed to support compliance rather than defining GDPR itself.

It is assumed that "create access to the Hospital Management System for at least all 7600 employees at the same time" refers to the technical capacity to handle concurrent authenticated sessions for 7600 employees and does not alter user authentication or authorization functionality described in other requirements.

It is assumed that duplicating every patient’s medical file for transfer to the National Database for Medical Records does not change the content of the medical file but only creates a copy in a format and location suitable for transfer.

It is assumed that access to the National Database for Medical Records is subject to external governance and legal constraints, and that this use case only covers establishing and using the technical interface as permitted.
It is assumed that no additional actors beyond those listed in the input are introduced for the purpose of this use case.
requirements_met: The system shall provide an Electronic Medical Record Database that has access to the National Database for Medical Records, so that UHOPE can gather the medical files of new patients.
The hospital management system shall be configured and operated in a manner that is compliant with GDPR regulations applicable to the processing of personal and medical data.
The hospital management system shall be available online 24 hours per day and 7 days per week under normal operating conditions, so that UHOPE employees can always do their job.
The data in the Electronic Medical Record Database shall be accessible 24 hours per day and 7 days per week under normal operating conditions, so that UHOPE employees can always do their job.
The hospital management system shall support concurrent access for at least 7600 UHOPE employees, so that every employee can perform their job.

The hospital management system shall maintain at least one current backup of every piece of information in the entire system at all times, so that data remains available even if an incident affects the primary system.
The system shall duplicate the medical file of every patient in a form that allows transfer to the National Database for Medical Records.
outstanding_issues: The specific technical and organizational measures required to demonstrate GDPR compliance for the hospital management system are not detailed and must be defined by legal and compliance stakeholders.
The acceptable maximum downtime, recovery time objectives, and recovery point objectives for the requirement "online 24 hours per day and 7 days per week" are not specified and must be agreed upon.
The detailed schedule, retention policy, and storage locations for backups "at all times" are not defined and must be established.
The network, hardware, and software capacity planning required to support 7600 concurrent employee sessions is not specified and must be determined.

The data format, messaging protocol, and security requirements for accessing and transferring medical files to the National Database for Medical Records are not described and must be provided by the national authority or integration documentation.

The governance rules defining when and how duplicated patient medical files are transferred to the National Database for Medical Records, and under what legal basis, are not specified and must be clarified.
The monitoring, alerting, and reporting mechanisms needed to verify continuous availability, backup status, and integration health are not specified and require further requirements analysis.
main_flow: 1. UHOPE defines system reliability and compliance objectives for the hospital management system → The system records the configured target objectives for availability, data backup coverage, GDPR compliance support, concurrent user capacity, and national database integration.

2. UHOPE configures the hospital management system to operate online 24 hours per day and 7 days per week → The system applies availability-related configurations and activates services to provide continuous online access under normal operating conditions.

3. UHOPE configures the Electronic Medical Record Database for continuous data access → The system applies configuration ensuring that electronic medical record data is accessible 24 hours per day and 7 days per week under normal operating conditions.

4. UHOPE configures the hospital management system to support at least 7600 concurrent employee accesses → The system allocates and validates sufficient technical capacity to handle at least 7600 concurrent authenticated employee sessions.

5. UHOPE defines and activates a backup strategy covering all information in the hospital management system → The system schedules and performs backup operations so that at least one current backup exists for every piece of information in the entire system.

6. UHOPE configures and enables access from the Electronic Medical Record Database to the National Database for Medical Records → The system establishes a secure and functional connection that allows the Electronic Medical Record Database to access medical records from the National Database for Medical Records as permitted.

7. UHOPE configures the system to duplicate each patient’s medical file for national transfer → The system duplicates every patient’s medical file in a form suitable for transfer to the National Database for Medical Records and stores the duplicated copies according to the configuration.

8. UHOPE verifies that GDPR-related configuration options are set according to organizational policies → The system enforces the configured GDPR-related controls and confirms that processing of personal and medical data is aligned with the defined configuration.

9. UHOPE reviews status indicators for availability, backup operations, concurrent access capacity, GDPR configuration, and national database integration → The system presents status information showing that availability, backups, concurrent access support, compliance configuration, and national database connectivity are all in an operational state.

10. UHOPE confirms completion of the reliability configuration process → The system finalizes and logs the reliability configuration as the active operational baseline for the hospital management system.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 4): If UHOPE decides to provision concurrent access capacity above 7600 employees while maintaining the minimum of 7600, UHOPE adjusts the concurrent access configuration to a higher capacity value → The system allocates resources to support the higher configured number of concurrent sessions and confirms that the configured capacity is at least 7600 → Flow returns to Step 5.

AF-2 (from Step 6): If UHOPE restricts access to only a subset of functions of the National Database for Medical Records, UHOPE configures the Electronic Medical Record Database integration to use only the allowed functions → The system limits national database interactions to the configured subset of functions while maintaining valid access for gathering medical files of new patients → Flow continues with Step 7.

AF-3 (from Step 8): If UHOPE updates internal GDPR policies after initial configuration, UHOPE revises the GDPR-related system configuration to match the updated policies → The system reapplies the updated GDPR-related settings and confirms that configuration is consistent with the new policies → Flow continues with Step 9.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 2): If the system cannot apply configurations to operate online 24 hours per day and 7 days per week due to infrastructure limitations, the system reports an availability configuration failure to UHOPE and logs the error → UHOPE may postpone completion of this use case until infrastructure is upgraded, and the use case terminates without achieving continuous system availability.

EF-2 (from Step 5): If the system cannot complete backup operations for all information due to storage or process failures, the system flags backup incompleteness, records the affected data scope, and notifies UHOPE → UHOPE may suspend reliance on the backup coverage until the issue is resolved, and the use case terminates without guaranteed backups for every piece of information.

EF-3 (from Step 6): If a connection to the National Database for Medical Records cannot be established or authenticated, the system indicates integration failure and logs diagnostic information → UHOPE is informed that access to the National Database for Medical Records is unavailable, and the use case terminates without functional national database integration.

EF-4 (from Step 7): If duplication of patient medical files cannot be completed for some or all patients, the system identifies the affected medical files, records the failure status, and notifies UHOPE → The use case terminates without full duplication of every patient’s medical file for transfer purposes.

EF-5 (from Step 8): If the system detects that required GDPR-related configuration options cannot be enforced due to system limitations, the system notifies UHOPE of the specific non-enforceable options and records the compliance risk → The use case terminates with the hospital management system not fully configured for GDPR compliance.

EF-6 (from Step 9): If status indicators reveal that any of the configured objectives for availability, backups, concurrent access capacity, GDPR configuration, or national database integration are not in an operational state, the system highlights the failed objectives and provides diagnostic information → UHOPE may choose to restart the configuration process in a separate execution of this use case, and the current execution terminates without meeting all postconditions.
information_for_steps: 1. Reliability objectives, availability objectives, backup objectives, GDPR compliance objectives, concurrent user capacity target, national database integration objectives
2. Availability configuration parameters, service activation settings, operating schedule definitions
3. Electronic Medical Record Database availability settings, data access configuration parameters
4. Concurrent user capacity value, resource allocation parameters, session management configuration
5. Backup strategy definition, backup schedule, backup scope definition for all system information, backup storage configuration
6. National Database for Medical Records connection parameters, authentication credentials, integration endpoint configuration
7. Patient medical file identifiers, duplication rules, duplication storage location, transfer format definition
8. GDPR-related configuration options, data processing policies, retention and access control parameters
9. System status indicators for availability, backup success metrics, concurrent session usage, GDPR configuration status, national database integration status
10. Reliability configuration approval record, configuration version identifier, configuration audit log entry
